thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Office market showing solid demand

title: Office market showing solid demand
text:
400 George Street, part of the sought after Investa portfolio.
The merged Commonwealth Government's amalgamated tribunal has signed a lease at 83 Clarence Street, managed by DEXUS Property â€“ a further indication that the office leasing and sales market is showing solid growth, according to agents.
Under the deal, the new group has leased 9500 square metres for 10 years, where it can hold hearings and also consolidate three offices across the city under one roof.
As part of the 2014 federal budget, the Commonwealth Government announced that as of July 1, this year, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Migration Review Tribunal, the Refugee Review Tribunal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Classification Review Board, were to be amalgamated into a single tribunal.
The tenant representative to the deal was Beau Stewart, director of corporate real estate at PCG, along with DEXUS' internal leasing agents.
Advertisement According to JLL's head of strategic research, Andrew Ballantyne, the lead indicators for the office leasing sector in the Sydney CBD are firm.
"We have seen positive results from business confidence and employment surveys, which are positive lead indicators for leasing inquiry and the underlying demand for office space," he said.
Sales have also been strong in the past three months.
Stephen McNabb, CBRE head of research, said for commercial property sales (of assets worth more than $5 million, across office, retail and industrial), the market has been solid, with $5.4 billion in sales for the three months to June 30. Foreign investors remain active, accounting for 35 per cent of transactions year to date compared with 19 per cent over the past 10 calendar years.
The part transaction (37.5 per cent) of International Tower 3 at Barangaroo to Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) accounted for one-third of the $1.7 billion of assets bought by foreigners during the quarter.
"NSW continues to attract the most capital among the states, having recorded the highest volume of transactions for four consecutive quarters," Mr McNabb said.
This comes as ownership of the Investa platform enters the next stage in the coming week, where the potential bidders will start talking in earnest to vendor Morgan Stanley and the Investa senior management.
It is said the final stage has five interested parties, Brookfield, whose infrastructure arm made a $9-billion bid for Australia's largest ports and rail operator, Asciano, last week; Cromwell, which has teamed up with South African real estate company, Redfine Properties; private equity giant Blackstone; DEXUS Property and its partner, the Middle Eastern fund, ADIA; as well as LaSalle Investment Management, which has teamed up with the Chinese Investment Corporation.
Bids for Investa's $6.5-billion platform, which comprises a portfolio of directly held assets, being a range of the country's best known skyscrapers including 400 George Street, Sydney, a management platform that spans the balance sheet assets, in addition to listed entity Investa Office Fund and its unlisted stablemate Investa Commercial Property Fund (ICPF), are due on Tuesday, July 7.
The mood among the bidders and the vendor is said to be cordial, but any new owner will have to negotiate a minefield of cross-ownership and pre-emptive rights of assets before any sales can occur.
